facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 374 of 1956 is an appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated December 19, 1955, of the Assam High Court in Revenue Appeal No. 33 M of 1955 and Civil Rule No. 76 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 374 of 1956. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated December 19, 1955, of the Assam High Court in Revenue Appeal No. 33 M  of 1955. Civil Rule No. 76 of 1955.

facts.text: The State of Assam settled the Charduar Brahmaputra Fishery with respondent No. 1 for three years from April 1, 1954, to March 31, 1957, at annual zama of Rs. 19,600 under r. 12 of the Fishery Rules.

anchor.surface_text: The State of Assam, respondent No. 3, had settled the Charduar Brahmaputra Fishery with the respondent No. I for a period of three years, viz., from April 1, 1954, to March 31, 1957, at an annual zama of Rs. 19,600 Under r. 12 of the Fishery Rules.

facts.text: Deputy Commissioner of Darrang received reports against respondent No. 1 alleging violation of cl. VI of the Fishery lease and other conditions.

anchor.surface_text: The Deputy Commissioner of Darrang, respondent No. 2, received some reports against the respondent No. 1 alleging violation of cl. VI of the Fishery lease and also of certain other companyditions of the lease.

facts.text: Deputy Commissioner obtained reports from the Sub-Deputy Collector and the Extra Assistant Commissioner regarding the allegations.

anchor.surface_text: He obtained reports from the Sub -Deputy Collector and the Extra Assistant Commissioner in regard to these allegations and came to the companyclusion that respondent No. 1 had created under-lease

facts.text: Deputy Commissioner concluded that respondent No. 1 created under-lease in favour of certain persons and cancelled the settlement of the fishery.

anchor.surface_text: came to the companyclusion that respondent No. 1 had created under-lease in favour of certain persons and cancelled the settlement of the fishery.

facts.text: State of Assam settled the fishery with the appellant with effect from May 4, 1955, after cancellation.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that after such cancellation, respondent No. 3, purporting to act again under r. 12, settled the said fishery with the appellant with effect from May 4, 1955,

facts.text: Respondent No. 1 was directed to give up possession of the fishery with effect from May 4, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: and respondent No. 1 was directed to give up possession thereof with effect from that date.

facts.text: Respondent No. 1 obtained a Rule from the Assam High Court alleging the settlement with appellant was illegal.

anchor.surface_text: Respondent No. 1 thereupon obtained a Rule from the Assam High Court alleging that the said settlement was absolutely illegal and the fishery had to be settled pro- perly

facts.text: Respondent No. 1 filed Revenue Appeal against the order of respondent No. 2 under rule 11 of section 1 of the Fishery Rules.

anchor.surface_text: A Revenue Appeal was also filed against the order of respondent No. 2 under rule 11 of section 1 of the Fishery Rules and both the Rule and the Revenue Appeal were heard together

facts.text: Assam High Court heard the Rule and Revenue Appeal together.

anchor.surface_text: and both the Rule and the Revenue Appeal were heard together by the Assam High Court.

facts.text: Assam High Court on August 31, 1955, in Civil Rule No. 56 of 1955, Nuruddin Ahmed v. State of Assam, declared r. 12 of the Fishery Rules ultra vires.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court had already on August 31, 1955, delivered a judgment in Civil Rule NO. 56 of 1955, Nuruddin Ahmed v. State of Assam  1 , declaring r. 12 of the Fishery Rules ultra vires

facts.text: Assam High Court held that respondent No. 3 had no jurisdiction to make settlement under r. 12 with respondent No. 1 and upheld cancellation on that ground alone.

anchor.surface_text: It followed that judgment and held that the respondent No. 3 had numberjurisdiction to make a settlement under A.I.R. 1956 Assam 48. r. 12 of the Fishery Rules with the respondent No. I

facts.text: Assam High Court dismissed the appeal of respondent No. 1.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal of respondent No. I was accordingly dismissed.

facts.text: Assam High Court held settlement with appellant was without jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: In regard to the appellant also the High Court came to the same companyclusion and held that the settlement made by respondent No. 3 in his favour was entirely without jurisdiction.

facts.text: Assam High Court made the Rule obtained by respondent No. 1 absolute.

anchor.surface_text: The Rule obtained by respondent No. I was accordingly made absolute.

facts.text: Assam High Court set aside settlements by respondent No. 3 with respondent No. 1 and appellant and directed fresh settlement.

anchor.surface_text: The result was that the settlements made by respondent No. 3 with respondent No. I and the appellant were both set aside and the authorities were directed to make a fresh settlement

facts.text: State of Assam did not obtain leave to appeal against the decision in Nuruddin Ahmed v. State of Assam.

anchor.surface_text: The State of Assam had number obtained any leave to appeal against the decision of the High Court in Nuruddin Ahmed v. State of Assam  1 ,

facts.text: Appellant obtained special leave to appeal against the High Court decision setting aside the settlement with him.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, however, obtained special leave to appeal against the decision of the High Court -which set aside the settlement of the Fishery made by respondent No. 3

facts.text: Supreme Court held that r. 12 of the Fishery Rules empowers State Government to settle fishery rights otherwise than by sale.

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, of opinion that r. 12 specifically empowers the State Government to settle the fishery rights otherwise than by sale and there is numberconflict

facts.text: Supreme Court declared the settlement of fishery rights by respondent No. 3 with the appellant valid and operative.

anchor.surface_text: The result, therefore, is that this appeal will be allowed and the settlement of fishery rights by respondent No. 3 with the appellant declared valid and operative.

facts.text: Supreme Court noted questions of fact involved in whether fishery lease of respondent No. 1 was validly cancelled.

anchor.surface_text: Logically enough respondent No. 1 also would have been entitled to a similar relief but there are various questions of fact involved in the determination of the question whether the fishery lease

facts.text: Judgment delivered on January 29, 1957 by BHAGWATI J.

anchor.surface_text: 1957. January 29. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by BHAGWATI J.-This appeal with special leave arises out of a judgment of the Assam High Court
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated December 19, 1955, of the Assam High Court in Revenue Appeal No. 33 M  of 1955.
The appellant, however, obtained special leave to appeal against the decision of the High Court -which set aside the settlement of the Fishery made by respondent No. 3

anchor.surface_text: The issue which was, therefore, contested between the appellant supported as he was by respondent No. 3, the State of Assam. and respondent No. I was as to the intra vires character of 12 of the Fishery Rules.

issues.text: whether there is any power conferred on the State Government by these rules to settle fisheries otherwise than by sale, e.g., by individual settlements without a settlement thereof by auction system or by tender system

anchor.surface_text: The question, therefore, which arises for our determination is whether there is any power conferred on the State Government by these rules to settle fisheries otherwise than by sale, e.g., by individual settlements without a settlement

arguments.claim: r. 12 gives specific power to State Government to settle fishery rights otherwise than by sale, even by individual settlements

anchor.surface_text: Reliance is accordingly placed on the provisions of r. 12 of the Fishery Rules and it is submitted that under that rule specific power is given to the State Government to settle the fishery rights otherwise than by sale. arguments.claim: s.16 does not prescribe principles or policy for rules on fishery rights

anchor.surface_text: There is absolutely nothing in the provisions of s. 16 which would go to show what are the principles on which such rules for the acquisition of fishery rights by the public or any person have to be made nor is there anything therein to indicate any policy which has to guide the State Government in the making of such rules.

arguments.claim: r.12 carves exception empowering State Government to settle otherwise than by sale

anchor.surface_text: No fishery is to be settled otherwise than by sale and that prohibition is general in terms but an exception is carved out in favour of the State Government in terms which are only capable of the construction that the State Government shall have the power of settling fishery rights otherwise than by sale.

arguments.claim: circumstances may require individual settlements e.g. after mid-term cancellation to maximize revenue

anchor.surface_text: Apart from the adoption of the tender system in place of the auction system, circumstances may conceivably arise where either by reason of the cancellation or relinquishment of fishery lease before the expiration of the period thereof ... the State Government may, under those circumstances, consider it desirable to enter into individual settlement of the fishery rights so as to earn for the State as much of revenue as possible.

arguments.claim: no conflict between s.16 and r.12

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, of opinion that r. 12 specifically empowers the State Government to settle the fishery rights otherwise than by sale and there is no conflict at all between the provisions of s. 16 of the Assam Land and Revenue Regulation, I of 1886, and r. 12 of the Fishery Rules.

arguments.claim: State of Assam v. Keshab Prasad Singh did not touch the present controversy; High Court judgment wrong
